title: Wollongong Wolves eye historic win in Australian Championship | Southern Highland News
body_text:
Meet your Wollongong Wolves players, charged with trying to win the inaugural Australian Championship.

The Wolves' return to the national stage can't come quickly enough for head coach Luke Wilkshire.
Wollongong kick off their Championship campaign in Tasmania against South Hobart on Sunday at 1pm.
The 16-team Championship is the dawn of a new era for Australian football and clubs such as the Wolves, looking to one day play in the A-League, the nation's top competition.
The Wolves, Australia's most successful regional sporting team in 2001, when it was crowned Oceania Club Champions, are one of eight foundation clubs in the Australian Championships, with the other eight spots filled by the champions of the respective National Premier League competitions around Australia.
Wollongong are in Group B alongside Marconi Stallions FC, Heidelberg United and South Hobart FC.
After six rounds of group stage matches, the top two teams from each group will advance to a knockout Finals Series, culminating in the Championship Final in early December.
As soon as Wilkshire was returned to the Wolves as head coach for the Australian Championship, the former Socceroo quickly set about strengthening the squad, which failed to make this season's NSW NPL finals.
His first signing was bringing Japanese international Kazuya Yamamura to Wollongong, highlighting the Wolves' stated ambitions to excel in the inaugural Championship.
Wilkshire recruited four more big names, including Thomas James and Tate Russell.
The recruits add to an already talented squad, which includes skipper Lachlan Scott and NSW NPL player of the year, Nicholas Olsen.
'This is huge for the region and the club," Wilkshire said.
"Being back on the national stage is an excellent opportunity for the club and the supporter base.
"The Championship is a great thing for football, and for clubs like ours to show what football means to the region.
"This is a new era for all clubs, for Australian football.
"There's only going to be one inaugural Australian Championship, so it's a great opportunity to do something special.
"It's exciting for football fans in Australia to have this competition.
"I believe all clubs, players and fans associated with it are excited to see it kick off."
The Wolves have strengthened their squad to achieve 'something special' for the region.
"I wanted to add quality and the right quality to the squad, which I believe we have," Wilkshire said.
"I'm delighted with the whole squad.
"In all my time being at the Wolves, this is definitely the most challenging for me in terms of even picking a match day squad and a starting 11.
"The boys have been great. We've got a lot of quality throughout; they're competing for places, and that's how you want it.
"I'm pleased with what we've got, and excited to see what they can do.
"We want to be the best we can be, we want to entertain, and we want to win football games.
"But you don't go into anything if you don't have the mentality and the ambition to win it. That's our goal, simple as that.
"We're putting the work in, we're going to go through the processes, and the outcome will take care of itself.
"The boys have been waiting for this moment to come.
"They've been putting in the work, we're prepared, now it's time for action."
Wilkshire admits to knowing little about South Hobart FC but expects a tough outing against Tasmania's most successful football club.
"It's even hard to get good video footage of their games and things like that, but obviously they've been the best team in Tasmania for decades," he said.
"They've got a lot of history down there, and rightly so, they are in the Championship for a reason.
"We treat them like any other opponent, with the utmost respect, and we are prepared to go there and put in a performance needed to get the job done."
Playing only six group games, the Championship teams had little time to find their feet.
"Games come thick and fast," Wilkshire said.
"[The Championship] has come upon us really quickly, and you don't have time or room for slip-ups. It's a Champions League-type competition, so every game is crucial.
"We are looking forward to kicking it off, getting a positive result in Hobart, and then getting back home to a full stadium here [Collegians Sports Centre on October 18]."
